ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also recorded lectures every week.
Weekly lecture.
Recorded lecture, virtual live seminar
Recorded lectures in Canvas along with virtual, synchronous discussion seminars.
Virtual lectures
Weekly recorded lecture by a different professor and twice weekly seminar discussion.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to deconstruct arguments, write philosophically, and understand complex philosophical texts.
Philosophical essay writing (which is a bit different from a typical essay), quick and thorough reading.
Philosophical analysis and logic
I learned analytical skills in regard to philosophy and how to better think about fundamental issues of being human.

The ability to write philosophy papers and think about philosophy. It's a great course for people who haven't taken a philosophy course before as there's a lot of support for those who haven't written Philosophy papers before.
I gained knowledge of the most important philosophers of the ancient world up until the middle ages and how to write a paper detailing and evaluating a philosophical argument.
Understanding the pillars of Ancient philosophy, learning how to write a philosophical analysis or reconstruction, and learning how to evaluate the strength of a philosophical argument.
Verbal and written communication, critical thinking, and creativity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed virtual seminars and didn't feel like they suffered because they were online.

Prof. Grimstad is a stellar seminar professor who moderated our discussions with expertise and zeal. Although I feel that sometimes our discussions could go more in depth, I could only blame the short duration of the seminar itself.

The course provides a wonderful introduction to classical philosophy. At times the course moved a bit fast, but this was just the nature of DS itself. The discussions over Zoom were really helpful in unpacking the concepts and ideas in the readings.
The discussions were very lively and enjoyable.  There is a lot of space to explore our own thoughts and philosophical positions.

Strengths: readings were engaging, class discussion was productive and exciting, we were able to have a close group despite being virtual 

Weaknesses: we sometimes would get so wrapped up in our discussion that we would not actually discuss the reading that we did for that day

The course required students to think beyond individualized opinions and consider the perspectives of a variety of authors, fellow classmates, and modern-day ideologies. It also created a highly welcoming environment in which each student felt compelled to share their ideas.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminars were successful
The interpersonal relationships between students and the professor were great and personal and did not suffer due to being online. The cohort bonded successfully.
Prof. Grimstad moderated Zoom discussions well and made conversation flow by using a handraising system.
The recorded lectures were really helpful, and the virtual discussion format closely mirrored the in-persin experience. This course was wonderfully adapted.

Despite the seminars being on zoom I thought our discussions were still very lively and engaging and we made the best out of it.  I would have liked to have used the raise hand zoom function during class instead of raising hands in the zoom window.
The virtual format actually worked well for this class. We used the chat function a lot to have another discussion separate from the main one

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.
Absolutely. Thinking about philosophy is my favorite pastime now that I have experienced it with other students in a virtual setting.

I cannot recommend Professor Grimstad enough. An excellent professor and wonderful teacher. Every seminar with him was filled with lively conversation, yet no one's opinions were ever looked over or undervalued. Beyond the DS syllabus, Professor Grimstad did a wonderful job of introducing us to the world of philosophy. If I  could take this class again, I definitely would.
Yes but only if they are curious about philosophy. I have come to the conclusion that an unexamined life is also worth living.

Yes, I would recommend this course if you are interested in classical philosophy. The conversations we had in class were always really interesting and engaging in thinking about fundamental questions on what it means to be human. This class was a great introduction to the main areas of classical philosophy, especially for someone without a large background in the subject.
Yes, I would recommend to anyone that is interested in philosophy.  I had never taken a philosophy course before and I thought it was a great introduction.
If you want an overview of the most important philosophers of the Western world and are willing to do a lot of reading and writing, take DS Philosophy.

Yes! This was my favorite class I took all semester. Not only did I learn a lot, but Prof. Grimstad is a wonderful and caring professor who really took the circumstances of our weird semester into account and made the class an absolute joy.

I would highly recommend this course. Students were encouraged to think originally and formulate their own opinions on topics that have been debated for centuries, while also acquiring skills such as quick thinking, written communication, and collaboration.
